name: Campaign
label: Campaign Builder
instructions: Use this form to expand an idea into a playable RPG campaign.

fields.name: changes
fields.label: Changes
fields.instructions: What changes are happening in the world?

fields.name: mood
fields.label: Mood
fields.instructions: Grim, exciting, zany, lyrical, tactical, dream-like, happy, sad, desparate, exuberent, etc. How will the players feel?

fields.name: visual_style
fields.label: Visual Style
fields.instructions: How do you see it in your mind? Does it look like a favorite movie, comic, artist, etc.?

fields.name: scope
fields.label: Scope
fields.instructions: A city, a planet, a war, a subculture, etc.

fields.name: end
fields.label: End
fields.instructions: Does this scenario have an end?

fields.name: driver
fields.label: Drivers
fields.instructions: These are pattens for writing playable adventures. Pick some and describe how they work in this case.

hints.label: Agents
hints.description: PCs work for someone who sends them on adventures. James Bond works for MI6. Rebels work for the Rebel Alliance. Brave knights work for their king. PCs can be an elite team. Or they might work in an obscure corner of some vast agency or corporation. And the varieties of jobs are endless. Consider The X-Files, Men in Black, Stargate, Outland, Agents of Shield, Battlestar Galactica, all the Star Treks, The Avengers, Blade Runner, and Torchwood.

hints.label: Secret War
hints.description:
The secret part allows the setting to look like our everyday world. (Or the everyday medieval world, etc.)

Secret War is often combined with Job With Missions. But it can also work without the chain of command. Vampires vs Werewolves, Magical threats vs Magical Defenders, etc. Characters can be part of one side by birth, or sucked in when they learn the secret.

hints.label: Freelancers
hints.description:
Paid freelancers include Ghostbusters(tm), private detectives, bodyguards, bounty hunters, assassins, hackers, mercenaries, etc. PCs can be guns for hire, swords for hire, spells for hire, cyberdecks for hire, or have fast ships, or other vehicles, for hire.

The PCs are contacted by their customers, and paid to go on adventures.

hints.label: Privateers
hints.description:
Privateers were like pirates who operated during a war. They had permission from their side to attack and rob ships belonging to the other side.

In traditional fantasy RPGs, parties of humans, elves, and dwarves are free to invade the homes of orcs, trolls, and goblins, dragons, and take their stuff.

hints.label: Quest
hints.description:
A long process, usually a journey, to get a single thing. Works best for short campaigns or as a nested driver. The advantage is a single crystal clear goal. The disadvantage is that it can be hard to stack a large number of adventures in front of that goal.

A quest can be nested inside a longer campaign.

Or the PCs might go about the business of the other driver, always alert for any clue that might allow them to advance their quest.

hints.label: Colony
hints.description: PCs are part of a group trying to make a new life in a new world. Use as the setting for one or more other drivers.

hints.label: Castaways
hints.description: PCs are lost or marooned away from their own kind. They explore, survive, and look for a way to get back home. (A large group of castaways might turn into a colony.)

hints.label: Journey
hints.description: A quest to get from point A to point B.

hints.label: Defenders of…
hints.description: …the world, their own group, their species, anyone weaker than them, normal people who don’t know The Secret, normal people without special powers, an oppressed/hated/hunted group, The King, the nation, the nation and it’s allies, an outpost, a castle, a nomadic band, etc…

hints.label: Defenders Against…
hints.description: …a supernatural threat, a sinister conspiracy, the other side of any of the above.

hints.label: Resistance
hints.description: …to invaders and oppressors.

hints.label: Revolution
hints.description: …against invaders and oppressors.

hints.label: Personal Mission
hints.description:
Or "personal quest". The PCs are doing something because they just really want to do it, or because they deeply believe it should be done.

They are driven to become the worlds greatest swordsman, to advance science, prove the Hollow Earth is real, or bring back Atalntis.

A PC with a personal quest and a personal fortune could employ like-minded PCs in Jobs With Missions.

hints.label: Disaster
hints.description: War, plague, asteroid, invasion, bacteria that eats plastic or computer chips, sudden climate change, AI take-over, etc. Best when combined with another driver.

hints.label: Survival
hints.description: Fire, food, shelter, dangerous animals. Often combined with Castaway. It’s a great component but hard to make a whole campaign out of it.

hints.label: Hunted
hints.description: The PCs are running and/or hiding from something. Kind of a downer by itself. But popular in fiction.

hints.label: Need
hints.description: The PCs have a dire need, which might or might not be shared with the rest of the world. Vampires need blood. Everyone needs water on a desert planet. Drasitic action is taken to find, obtain, and protect the vital resource.

hints.label: Escape
hints.description: A kind of Quest. A desperate journey to Anywhere Else. Powerful, but hard to run very long by itself.

hints.label: Merchants
hints.description:
Merchant adventurers exist when great dangers and difficulties separate supply and demand. Think of the early spice traders in Earth’s Age of Exploration, the caravans along the Silk Road, or maybe the fur traders of the American frontier.

An adventurous trading life could form the backdrop for other adventures. This is the classic “fast ship” scenario.

And an actual green eyeshade, counting the gold pieces kind of campaign really appeals to some players (and is totally boring to others).

hints.label: Smugglers
hints.description:
Independent smugglers, who buy low on one side of a border and sell high on the other are a classic kind of merchant adventurers. Smugglers might also work for a gang or a rich buyer (or seller) who sends them on missions. Either way, it’s a model with a built in opposition.

However, smugglers are trying their hardest to avoid excitement and conflict. So maybe mix this one with another driver, either by adding some smuggling within another driver, or by making the smugglers open to other kinds of jobs. (They have a fast ship…)

hints.label: Build Power and Resources
hints.description:
A core component of many successful RPGs. And it works great with all the other drivers.

Note that I didn’t say “build wealth”. That by itself leads to the treasure hunter’s dilemma. Either it goes slowly and is too much like a normal job, or it goes quickly and the PCs retire.

But players’ appetite for power seems to be endless. And it’s extra-motivating when the resources are needed for some other driver’s goal.

hints.label: Keys Quest
hints.description:
A classic… The Great Magic Thing was divided into parts. The parts were scattered and hidden in dangerous places. And the PCs have a reason to find them.

Like all quests, it has a final end. But it has a bunch of intermediate ends, too. Twelve parts automatically gives you twelve adventures. Stretch it to a few adventures per part and you can get a whole year of play.

It’s over-used. But it’s over-used because it works.

hints.label: Power and Responsibility
hints.description: The PCs are some of the most powerful and important people in their world. So the world's problems become their problems.

hints.label: Wandering Heros
hints.description:
PCs have explicitly signed up to fight evil and help those in need. Examples: Knights of the Round Table, Dr. Who, The A-Team.

This is popular and a classic. But you should make sure the players explicitly agree to it, because it requires the PCs to do dangerous things without any other rational motivation.

hints.label: Treasure Hunters
hints.description:
Treasure hunters seek valuables that have no current owner. They are popular in fiction. And raiding a dangerous tomb is a straightforward adventure. This it a very simple driver, which is both its greatest strength and its greatest weakness.

Also, treasure hunters who are after the Big Score will either get tired of failing, or succeed and retire. So consider mixing this with at least on other driver. Or start with it and transition to something else.

fields.name: toy
fields.label: Toys and Treasures
fields.instructions: Things the players will love using. Common categories include...

fields.name: place
fields.label: Places
fields.instructions: Describe some places where the action happens.

fields.name: side
fields.label: Sides
fields.instructions: Groups or important individuals, or dragons or gods, etc. These can be outright foes, or anyone with interests different enough that you might have to negotiate with them.

fields.name: pcs_are
fields.label: The PCs are...
fields.instructions: Write a few lines about who PCs are in all this.

fields.name: adventure
fields.label: Adventures
fields.instructions: How can you run some of these classic adventure types?

hints.label: Assault
hints.description: Attack a place to achieve a goal.

hints.label: Siege
hints.description: Defend a place

fields.name: character_class
fields.label: Character Classes
fields.instructions: Types of people in this world, who they are, and what they do. The rules don't have to be class based. Classes are just an awesome way to tell players about a world.

fields.name: players_intro
fields.label: Players' Introduction
fields.instructions: Tell the players about the world

fields.name: pc_creation_notes
fields.label: PC Creations Notes
fields.instructions: Tell the players who they are, and who they can be.

fields.name: first_adventure
fields.label: First Adventures
fields.instructions: Sketch some adventures to draw the player into the world.
